Within a year of the U.S. entering WW2, Roosevelt established a new US Army division (roughly 10,000 - 15,000 men) composed entirely of people with knowledge and experience at building and developing infrastructure. People like engineers, architects, carpenters, plumbers, electricians, road builders, etc. They spent almost four years preparing for the day they'd go to Germany, and other nations, to rebuild what was destroyed by war.
At no time, did anyone have to answer questions about their loyalty to a political party, to Roosevelt personally, or on subjects having nothing to do with their jobs (like abortion).

Fast forward to 2003. We conquered Iraq, and now had to rebuild it. But according to a multitude of books looking into it, turns out the people put in charge of putting together the rebuilding staffers all came from places like the Federalist Society, the Cato Institute and other rightwing thinktanks. And the first questions they asked anyone seeking to help rebuild Iraq had nothing to do with skills or training. No, they asked questions about whether or not you felt personal loyalty to President Bush; did you believe that only a totally unregulated free-market economy could work; your views on abortion, etc.

Turned out, the people chosen to rebuild Iraq almost never had the basic skills necessary to do the job, but were instead political apparatchiks chosen for their GOP loyalty and their ideological purity. No wonder Iraq collapsed as it did...
And your point is what? That Paul Krugman has been a Secret Agent for the GOP's Right Wing for the past 30 years?

I am a woman near Hillary's age and I'm a staunch supporter and admirer since she first came on the national political scene in the early '90s, and especially since she ran for Senator from New York in 2000. I am thrilled that she is running for President, not only because of the prospect of having a woman in the Oval Office -- although that is a big part of it for me -- but mostly because she is the most qualified of any of the candidates running on either Party ticket. As for Bernie, in my view he is a delusional wingnut who is not close enough to Hillary in experience, savvy, strength, knowledge -- especially in the areas of foreign policy, healthcare and reforming the financial industry -- to breathe the same air.

Every woman who has lived long and experienced what women have over the past half century know that it takes women longer than men to climb the ladder. Hillary has made that climb brilliantly. In our deeply troubled times -- in which President Obama has done a remarkable job in leading us out of the catastrophic situation caused by the Bush Administration -- Hillary is the only one with the head on her shoulders to lead the nation so that we can solve our domestic problems while continuing to stand tall on the global stage. And she's the only one who will allow me to sleep at night, without one eye open.

I blame this primarily on the Democratic Party.

I use to be from the early- to mid-1800s that the Democratic Party was understood to be derived from a Jefferson-Jackson tradition; hence, the annual Jeff-Jack Day BBQ parties to this day around the country, though less so now.

But Thomas Jefferson was the aristocrat, enlightenment thinker and owner sipping sherry while penning big thoughts1- - Andrew Jackson was the born to poor stock, get-your-hands-dirty scraper and worker swilling whiskey.

In America, and in the Democratic Party, the two were understood to make up the sum and whole of not just the party but also the nation.

Then we ended up with soft, cosmopolitian internationalist with pedigrees as the Democratic politicans who were elites - Dukakis, Clinton, Gore, Kerry, Obama, Hillary.

You don't see a Truman, Johnson or Carter on that list do you? No. They were all Jacksonians to a fault, born of poor dirt farmers, and they worked their way up - - and here's the key part - - kept their common touch, lack of ego, and understood "ordinary people". There were Jeffersonian presidents too, like Wilson, FDR and JFK.

But come 1972, and in the following decade, we saw the Jacksonians alienated from the Dem Party's rush to the left - - pro-abortion, insultingly against traditional marriage and roles, forced-busing of kids, anti-Vietnam, down-right anti-American, seemingly. Jeffersonians took over.

Now Jacksonian Democrats are tempid Republican and considering Trump...

Except that Jackson was the apostle of slavery and westward expansion, where poor white dirt farmers found themselves breeding large broods of farmhands to help them compete with considerably cheaper slave labor of large estates.

The McPlantation economy was a product of Jefferson and Jackson ... and it didn't work out so well for the working class, or indigenous people. Working class and upper class folk have ample reason to get all hot and bothered when asked to buy tickets to a J-J Dinner.

Clinton and Obama, yes - - Hillary, no. Her family was quite comfortable.

But what I reference is not a numeric income number or "growing-up" in modest means factor - - but more, the previous existence of two very diverse but very complimentary schools in the Democratic Party.

Obama, Clinton and Hillary and the others, all adopted a path (ie Yale, Harvard, Oxford...) that was very elite in substance and trappings - - and became disconnected from ordinary folk. Bill Clinton, in his head at least, was likely the only one of the lot who kept that Jacksonian approach amidst a lot of Jeffersonian hub-bub. That was his polularity and APPEARANCE of being grounded in Jacksonian ways.

Now all three walk about as millionaires, and we have Obama quoting arugula prices on the campaign trail...

Disconnected from most people - - whereas, the man is an underdeveloped, narccisstic, loudmouth teenager, Trump - - but he is connected to common sense still and asks about things that should be asked about. "Elites" do not.

Reagan Democrats arose because of this slidding divorce by Dems from Andrew Jackson's ways on all levels. I would rather be in a bar fight with a Truman, Tip O'Neill, Scoop Jackson (not related to Andrew), Nunn or LBJ at my side -- rather than an Obama, Gore or Dukakis, Pelossi, Schumer, Reid...

We need both, that is Presidents and leaders who can or appreciate thinking like a PhD, but who can still win a bar fight. Hence, union members "going Trump". SF
